Target description: By 2030, eradicate extreme poverty for all people everywhere, currently measured as people living on less than $1.25 a day
Justification: The heavy dependence on imported equipment, technology, and expertise for green hydrogen production and end-use poses a risk of limiting the economic benefits and job opportunities that could have been generated domestically. Additionally, if investments and policies related to green hydrogen prioritize foreign entities or neglect the inclusion of local communities, it has the potential to worsen existing disparities and hinder poverty reduction efforts. In the case of Africa, green hydrogen production can pose the highest risk (red flag) to the progress towards the target due to poor working conditions and lower gross domestic product/purchasing power parity per capita compared to those of other countries. In general, the ability to manufacture key equipment within the country reduces the risk of various social indicators closely related to this target, such as fair salaries and social security expenditures.

Justification: Green hydrogen value chain has positively potential to influence the adoption of various mitigation measures, drive the deployment of renewable energy technologies, facilitate the implementation of sustainable agriculture methods, enhance water management systems, seasonal storage, and establish governance frameworks that promote climate resilience. Green hydrogen production can increase renewable energy production capacity by replacing fossil fuels and decreasing greenhouse gas emissions. The transportation can provide system integration (e.g. seasonal storage) and avoid using fossil fuels, as seen in India. In the end-use, green hydrogen can decarbonize hard-to-abate sectors (e.g. steel, cement, chemical industry, refineries, and aluminum). All these actions can mitigate the potentially catastrophic impacts of climate change. Most countries have already worked on mitigation actions to 2030, using green hydrogen. To meet this target, the presence of the entire value chain at the local level can provide clean energy solutions that mitigate climate-related risks and create local economic stability.

By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination
Justification: Adopting green hydrogen as a clean energy source may support efforts to reduce the adverse effects of pollution and contamination and may be the optimal strategy for air pollution mitigation, mainly replacing fossil fuels. In addition, green hydrogen has the positive potential to decarbonize multiple sectors reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Green hydrogen production can contribute to the replacement of fossil fuels and decrease pollution when the electricity used to produce green hydrogen comes from green methods. Green hydrogen transportation remains a challenge when fossil fuels are used as the fuel source for transporting green hydrogen, for example, in ships. However, green ammonia and green hydrogen may become the main fuel for zero carbon emissions of ships in the future. Green hydrogen end-use can reduce air pollution and avoid deaths and breathing illnesses, particularly in sectors such as transport. In some European countries, there are actions to decarbonize the transport sector by 2030, mainly to avoid local pollution. Meanwhile, in developing countries, replacing fossil fuels in this freight transportation is one of the main challenges foreseen in the medium-term.
